trans-unit.source:
Thank you for taking the time (~10 minutes) to respond to this survey!

Some students who you teach are participating in a research project studying how children learn and develop. Your responses in this survey should apply to your classroom, school, and professional beliefs rather than to any one specific child.

This survey has two parts: Part A and Part B.

In Part A, the questions relate to your background and beliefs.

In Part B the questions are classroom specific. If you teach more than one class of students included in this project, you will complete Part B separately for each classroom.

If you teach a single subject, please complete the questions that relate to other subjects to the best of your knowledge or consult with a colleague for those details only.

Thank you for your participation! Your responses provide invaluable insight into the education of your students.

When you are ready to begin, select the “Start Survey” button.

Thank you!
PART A: The following questions ask about your background, the school where you teach, your feelings about your job, and your beliefs about teaching and children.
This set of questions asks about your background.
What is your current age?
years of age
What is your gender?
Other (please describe)
What is the highest level of education you have completed?
Less than high school
GED or High school equivalency
Some college but no degree
High school diploma or equivalent, plus technical training or certificate
Associate's degree
Bachelor's degree
Master's degree
Doctoral degree
Indicate your undergraduate field of study. Mark ALL that apply.
Early childhood education
Elementary education
Special education
Child development
Reading specialist
Curriculum and instruction
Bilingual/bicultural education
Other education related major (ex: secondary education, educational psychology, education administration, music education, etc.). Please specify:
Non-education major. Please specify:

Please specify non-education major:

Counting this school year, how many years have you been a schoolteacher? (please round to the nearest year)
Less than one year
1 to 2 years
3 to 5 years
6 to 10 years
Over 10 years
This set of questions asks about the school where you currently teach.
Counting this school year, how many years have you been teaching at this school? (please round to the nearest year)
Please indicate how much you agree or disagree with the following statements about this school.
Strongly Disagree
Disagree
Agree
Strongly Agree
I feel accepted and respected as a colleague by most staff members.
Parents are supportive of school staff.
Students feel supported and comfortable in this school.
Staff feel supported and comfortable in this school.
Students are safe when here at this school.
Staff are safe when here at this school.
The facilities and property of this school are kept up well.
The facilities and property of this school are clean.
Ongoing collaboration is something adults in this school do well.
Adults working in this school have strong professional relationships.
Adults working in this school are respectful and supportive of one another.
With this set of items, we wish to learn more about teachers' feelings about their job.
Please select one answer that indicates how often you agree with each of the following statements.
Never
A few times a year or less
Once a month or less
A few times a month
Once a week
A few times a week
Everyday
I feel emotionally drained from my work.
I feel fatigued when I get up in the morning and have to face another day on the job.
I can easily understand how my students feel about things.
I deal very effectively with the problems of my students.
I feel burned out from my work.
I feel I'm positively influencing other people's lives through my work.
I feel frustrated by my job.
I feel I'm working too hard on my job.
I can easily create a relaxed atmosphere with my students.
I feel exhilarated after working closely with my students.
I have accomplished many worthwhile things in this job.
I feel like I'm at the end of my rope.
In my work, I deal with emotional problems very calmly.
This set of questions is designed to help us gain a better understanding of the kinds of things that create difficulties for teachers in their school activities.
How much influence do you have...
Never
Very Little
Some Influence
Quite a Bit
A Great Deal
on disruptive behavior in the classroom?
to motivate children who show low interest in activities?
to get children to believe they can do well on activities?
to help children in your classroom(s) value learning?
on getting children to follow classroom rules?
on calming a child who is disruptive or noisy?
How well can you...
Not At All
Very Little
Somewhat
Quite a Bit
A Great Deal
establish a classroom management system?
use a variety of assessment strategies?
provide alternative explanations or examples when children are confused?
assist families in helping their children do well in school?
implement alternative strategies in your classroom(s)?
create good questions for children in your classroom(s)?
With this set of items, we wish to learn more about teachers' ideas and beliefs about children.
Please select one answer that indicates how strongly you agree with each of the following statements.
Strongly Disagree
Mildly Disagree
Mildly Agree
Strongly Agree
Since parents lack special training in education, they should not question the teacher's teaching methods.
Children should be treated the same regardless of differences among them.
Children should always obey the teacher.
Preparing for the future is more important for a child than enjoying today.
Children will not do the right thing unless they must.
Children should be allowed to disagree with their parents if they feel their own ideas are better.
Children should be kept busy with work and study at home and at school.
The major goal of education is to put basic information into the minds of the children.
In order to be fair, a teacher must treat all children alike.
The most important thing to teach children is absolute obedience to whoever is in authority.
Children learn best by doing things themselves rather than listening to others.
Children must be carefully trained early in life or their natural impulses will make them unmanageable.
Children have a right to their own point of view and should be allowed to express it.
Children's learning results mainly from being presented basic information again and again.
Children like to teach other children.
The most important thing to teach children is absolute obedience to parents.
